title: Multi-Cloud Complexity Multiplier
context: Multi-cloud strategy sounds like good risk management. Don't put all your eggs in one basket. Run workloads across AWS, GCP, and Azure so no single provider can hold you hostage. The CTO presents it to the board as a vendor lock-in mitigation strategy. In practice, multi-cloud multiplies every operational challenge by the number of clouds. Each provider has different networking models, IAM systems, storage APIs, monitoring tools, and pricing structures. Your team must become expert in all of them simultaneously. The lowest-common-denominator approach — abstracting away cloud-specific features — means you pay premium prices for commodity capabilities while losing the managed services that justify cloud adoption in the first place. Most companies that attempt multi-cloud end up with one primary cloud and expensive, underutilized secondary deployments.
hypothesis: Multi-cloud prevents vendor lock-in and improves resilience.

effects.label: Operational complexity multiplies per cloud
effects.impact: 3 clouds = 3x networking, IAM, monitoring, billing expertise

children.label: Each cloud has different networking models — VPC peering, firewall rules, DNS
IAM policies are incompatible — separate identity systems per cloud
Monitoring requires separate tooling or expensive multi-cloud observability platforms

effects.label: Lowest-common-denominator architecture wastes cloud advantages
effects.impact: Can't use managed services that are cloud-specific

children.label: Abstraction layers add latency and complexity to avoid cloud-specific APIs
Pay cloud prices for capabilities you could get from commodity infrastructure

effects.label: Team expertise dilutes across providers
effects.impact: Engineers become mediocre at 3 clouds instead of expert at 1

children.label: Hiring requires multi-cloud experience — smaller talent pool, higher salaries
Incident response slower — team must context-switch between cloud consoles
Training budget triples to maintain certifications across providers

effects.label: Data transfer costs create hidden tax

children.label: Data gravity keeps most workloads on primary cloud anyway
Egress costs make cross-cloud communication prohibitively expensive at scale

dontIf: Your primary motivation is theoretical vendor lock-in risk rather than a concrete business requirement
Your team has fewer than 20 infrastructure engineers
ifYouMust: Designate one cloud as primary (80%+ of workloads) and use secondary only for specific, justified use cases
Use cloud-agnostic tooling only at the orchestration layer (Terraform, Kubernetes) not the application layer
Calculate the actual cost of multi-cloud including team scaling, training, and egress before committing
Negotiate enterprise agreements with your primary cloud — the discount often exceeds the lock-in risk

alternatives.name: Single cloud with multi-region
alternatives.note: Deploy across regions within one provider for resilience without multi-cloud complexity

alternatives.name: Cloud-agnostic at the container layer only
alternatives.note: Kubernetes on one cloud, with tested migration runbooks for emergency provider switch

alternatives.name: Best-of-breed per workload
alternatives.note: Use each cloud for what it does best (e.g., GCP for ML, AWS for everything else) without trying to abstract

seo.description: Multi-cloud multiplies operational complexity by the number of clouds. Teams become mediocre at 3 providers instead of expert at 1. Most workloads stay on the primary cloud anyway.
